title: Orange County R Users Group (OCRUG): Book club  - Communicating with Data  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Are you looking to improve your data communication skills? Come just us for a book club. It will be headed up by Neal Fultz. The idea is to motivate us to read books and discussing them together. This will help all of us to develop our skills.

The format will be that the leader will prepare a short summary of the material and present it to the group. We will then discuss the material and do some exercises.

The expectations are that you will attend regularly. If you cannot make a commitment to attend, please wait until the next book club starts. It is also expected that participants will take turns being the leader. The leader should prepare a summary of the material that was read and present it to the group.

We will meet each week, Wednesday between 3:30 and 5:00 PM PST for eight weeks.

Book: Title: Communicating with Data: The Art of Writing for Data Science
Dead Tree: https://global.oup.com/academic/product/communicating-with-data-9780198862758

Signing up: When you sign-up you will be placed on the waiting list. We always have a lot of interest but the book club is a significant commitment. The coordinator will confirm your commitment. Please make sure that you get meet-up emails.

title: The Chicago R User Group (CRUG): Rebooting...Live at the Haymarket Pub, Lightning Talks & Open Mic! üéâ üçª üéâ üç∑, United States, US/Canada
description:
Please join us in rebooting the Chicago R User Group with an evening of lightning talks and an open mic, live and in person!

**Doors open at 5:00, talks begin at 5:30!**

The pandemic kept many of us inside, writing copious amounts of new code for our hobbies & jobs. In the spirit of Open Source we welcome you, Chicagoland R users, to attend and consider contributing a short talk on the novel work you're proud of. As always, slides including simple code that can be displayed in a readable way is encouraged. Register here to present and/or just Bring Your Own Slide Deck! (https://forms.gle/oE7pXjkUzKyXuvQH9)

Open Mic: impromptu 5-10 minute talk on any R topic, on a FIFO basis. Scheduled Lightning Talks as follows, ordered by submission time:

Jeff Ryan (https://www.linkedin.com/in/jeffreyaryan/) on his mmap package: A tasty introduction to the power of memory mapping infinite data, with examples from astronomy and finance.

Rob Creel (https://www.linkedin.com/in/robcreel/) on Data Tidying Horror Stories: A quick exposition of lessons learned in wrangling data from varied sources.

Anh Tran (https://www.linkedin.com/in/anh-n-tran/) on Data Analysis for a local non-profit addressing the mental health treatment of incarcerated individuals.

Arafath Hossain (https://www.linkedin.com/in/arafath-hossain/) on using R to augment the ETL process.

Joseph Retzer (https://www.linkedin.com/in/josephretzer/) on Visualizing Non-Hierarchical Cluster Allocation Using Alluvial Diagrams in R.

Eugene Kravchenko (https://www.linkedin.com/in/eugenekravchenko/) on using R for to reproduce momentum investing methods decribed in Meb Faber's Tactical Asset Allocation, in the era of COVID-19.

Troy Hernandez, CRUG organizer (https://www.linkedin.com/in/troy-hernandez/): Prodromal Labor or Early Labor? Predicting Active Labor with a Linear Model (n=1)

** We are monitoring daily infection counts (currently falling) and will adjust the parameters of this event based on guidance from the City of Chicago and local experts in the field **

As vaccination rates continue to increase, Governor Pritzker has issued guidelines for all Illinois Businesses to reopen on June 11th! (https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/news-item.aspx?ReleaseID=23399)
In step with the Governor, Chicago Mayor Lori Lightfoot has moved up the city's time table to match the state of Illinois, and will also fully reopen on June 11th! (https://www.reuters.com/world/us/chicago-reopen-fully-june-11-mayor-says-2021-06-04/)

Given our commitment to gathering safely, we are incentivizing vaccination of all in attendance by giving you FREE beverage tickets if you can display proof of receiving a COVID-19 vaccine. So bring your vaccine card and enjoy a beverage! üç∑üçª üç∑üçª

But wait...there's more! You may also receive a free plastic sleeve to protect your vaccine card. However, in the spirit of Reduce, Reuse, Recycle ‚ôª (hat tip, Troy Hernandez) you should reuse one of the many lanyards you've acquired from the conference circuit if possible.

If you aren't vaccinated, you still have time as doses are becoming widely available! Please visit the Illinois Department of Health COVID-19 Vaccine FAQ page for more details. (https://www.dph.illinois.gov/covid19/vaccine-faq)

As always, please reach out to us with any questions or concerns. We look forward to seeing you live and in person at the Haymarket Pub & Brewery soon!

title: Central Iowa R User Group: R and Python study group, United States, US/Canada
description:
Until we can meet again in person, please join our Slack workspace to stay in touch, ask questions, and share information throughout the week.

https://join.slack.com/t/centraliowarusergroup/shared_invite/zt-dhfa5ude-0tvHascxRkn2pgiqDdQgrw

The Slack workspace is available any time, not just Saturday mornings.

Are you tired of learning and playing with Python and R alone? Would you like to get together with a few friends and learn together? I have been starting to learn R and Python for data science and following the typical route of videos and practice projects. I really want to ramp up my learning and exposure to different ways. Here is my proposal:

- Gather a small group of 2-5 and learn together.
- Meet at a coffee shop, library, or some other space that has Wi-Fi.
- Pick a project, data set or problem, then work to solve it with different tools.
- Keep it fluid and informal.
- Meet on a regular basis, say weekly to start, and adjust as needed.
- Aim to keep the meetings 2-4 hours long, but this can be adjusted to the project or group. People can come and go as needed.
- It does not have to be the same people each time, so you only have to commit to going once to check it out.

Are you interested? Show up at the meeting spot, have some coffee, meet new friends and bring a project or question.

title: R Users & R-Ladies Warsaw (Spotkania Entuzjast√≥w R): Why R? Webinar 046 - Genomics @ Cloud with R  [Virtual] , Poland, Europe
group: R Users & R-Ladies Warsaw (Spotkania Entuzjast√≥w R)
description:
STREAM - https://youtu.be/3RkBEva4xRk
YouTube Channel - https://www.youtube.com/WhyRFoundationVideos

DESCRIPTION OF THE TALK

R and R-Bioconductor libraries are the popular tools in the genomics space,enabling researchers, clinicians and pharma to harness the power of -omic data,enabled through the entire portfolio of bioinformatics/biostatistics methods. Thissession will provide a foundational overview of genomics and introduce cloudenvironment‚Äôs rapidly growing portfolio of products and services for genomics dataanalysis with R. Talk will provide a glimpse into how cloud technologies are beingleveraged by different research partners to further their research and developmentactivities in advancing precision medicine, healthcare and beyond. Attendees will beintroduced to rapidly growing opportunities within genomics & healthcare in thecloud, understand R and R-Bioconductor‚Äôs best practices in genomics and beprovided resources to additional information about genomics opportunities,Genomics Data Science approaches and developments in healthcare.

BIOGRAPHY

Erdal Cosgun, Ph.D, ÔÅ°
- Senior Data and Applied Scientist, Genomics Team, Microsoft Research & AI
- Affiliated Assoc.Prof

Erdal Cosgun graduated from the Department of Statistics, Faculty of Science atHacettepe University in 2007. He started his Ph.D. research as a research assistantat the Department of Biostatistics of the same university. He worked in the Sectionon Statistical Genetics, Department of Biostatistics at the University of Alabama inBirmingham for 6 months in 2009. He received a 3-month bioinformatics training atthe R&D Campus at Pfizer Inc. and received a full scholarship from the company in2011. After finishing his Ph.D., he worked as an Asst. Prof. at Acƒ±badem University,Faculty of Medicine, Department of Biostatistics and Medical Informatics as Head ofthe Department. He has published over 40 original scientific papers and severalpresentations at conferences, particularly focused on statistical genetics andgenomics data science. He joined Microsoft as a Global Black Belt-TSP on AdvancedAnalytics in 2015. He was responsible for Machine Learning operations across theMEA region. He has been working at Microsoft Genomics since December 2016 as aSenior Data and Applied Scientist. He is also an ‚ÄòAssociate Professor of Biostatistics‚Äôaffiliated with Council of Higher Education in Turkey and Biostatistics editor of theTurkish Journal of Biochemistry (SCI).

title: R Users & R-Ladies Warsaw (Spotkania Entuzjast√≥w R): X-Europe Webinar Causal Inference Approach to Matching in Two-Sided Marketplaces  [Virtual] , Poland, Europe
group: R Users & R-Ladies Warsaw (Spotkania Entuzjast√≥w R)
description:
REGISTER HERE: https://webinar-causal-inference.carrd.co/

### ABOUT SPEAKER
Data scientist, social scientist, statistician, and software developer. Sean mostly specializes in methods for solving causal inference and business decision problems, and particularly interested in building tools for practitioners working on real-world problems. He is a generalist, who likes to hang out with people from many fields and borrow as many ideas as possible. He has collaborated with computer scientists, economists, political scientists, statisticians, machine learning researchers, and business school scholars. It‚Äôs fun for Sean to jump around a bit, continue learning new things and make connections between fields. Background: Ph.D. student at NYU‚Äôs Stern School of Business, ex-research scientist and manager on Facebook‚Äôs Core Data Science Team and currently head of the Rideshare Labs team at Lyft. https://seanjtaylor.com/

### ABOUT TALK
Improving two-sided marketplaces like Lyft's ridesharing business is accomplished when we implement better matching algorithms that create more efficient allocations. However, marketplaces generate complex causal graphs which make counterfactuals difficult to reason about and estimate. I describe the causal effects of matching we must estimate to allocate drivers to requests, and the potential confounding problems that bias estimates from more standard machine learning approaches. We will then discuss how causal inference ideas can be applied in related settings like search, ranking, and recommender systems.

### ABOUT THE X-EUROPE DATA SCIENCE WEBINARS
X-Europe Webinar Series is a joint online event of Vienna Data Science Group, Data Science Croatia, Frankfurt Data Science, Budapest Data Science Meetup, BCN Analytics, Budapest.AI, Barcelona Data Science and Machine Learning Meetup, Budapest Deep Learning Reading Seminar, Warsaw R Users Group, PyData Slovakia, and Data Scientists Ireland.

title: Greater Boston useR Group (R Programming Language): shiny.fluent and shiny.react: Build beautiful Shiny apps (June useR Meetup)  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
group: Greater Boston useR Group (R Programming Language)
description:
shiny.fluent and shiny.react: Build beautiful Shiny apps using Microsoft's Fluent UI
Presentation by Kamil ≈ªy≈Ça

Abstract:
In this talk we will present the functionality and ideas behind a new open-source package Appsilon developed called shiny.fluent. UI plays a huge role in the success of Shiny projects. shiny.fluent enables you to build Shiny apps in a novel way using Microsoft‚Äôs Fluent UI as the UI foundation. It gives your app a beautiful, professional look and a rich set of components while retaining the speed of development that Shiny is famous for.

Fluent UI is based on the Javascript library React, so it‚Äôs a challenging task to make it work with Shiny. We have put the parts responsible for making this possible in a separate package called shiny.react, which enables you to port other React-based components and UI libraries so that they work in Shiny.

During the talk we will demonstrate how to use shiny.fluent to build your own Shiny apps, and explain how we solved the main challenges in integrating React and Shiny

Speaker Bio:
Kamil is a Full Stack Engineer at Appsilon. He graduated with degrees in Computer Science and Mathematics from the University of Warsaw. He is passionate about working across various technologies, leading projects, and developing internal tooling. Privately, he enjoys listening to
jazz and has an interest in psychology and philosophy.

description:

TigerGraph Cloud, a cloud-agnostic database-as-a-service offering, enables users to leverage graph analytics on AWS, Azure, and GCP. TigerGraph Cloud not only fully manages clusters, but also provides a use case library via starter kits, which greatly reduces customers‚Äô time to business value and decreases the learning curve to specific graph database use cases such as fraud detection, recommendation, customer 360, AI, and in-database machine learning.

Come learn and ask questions from our TigerGraph Cloud Product Team and watch an end-to-end overview of TigerGraph Cloud with a short demonstration that showcases starter kits and other unique functionality.

title: Montreal R User Group: Speed Optimization & Benchmarks in Spark NLP 3: Making the Most of Hardware  [Virtual] , Canada, US/Canada
description:
Register: https://events.johnsnowlabs.com/speed-optimization-benchmarks-in-spark-nlp-3-making-the-most-of-modern-hardware

Spark NLP is the most widely used NLP library in the enterprise, thanks to implementing production-grade, trainable, and scalable versions of state-of-the-art deep learning & transfer learning NLP research. It is also Open Source with a permissive Apache 2.0 license that officially supports Python, Java, and Scala languages backed by a highly active community and JSL members.

Spark NLP library implements core NLP algorithms including lemmatization, part of speech tagging, dependency parsing, named entity recognition, spell checking, multi-class and multi-label text classification, sentiment analysis, emotion detection, unsupervised keyword extraction, and state-of-the-art Transformers such as BERT, ELECTRA, ELMO, ALBERT, XLNet, and Universal Sentence Encoder.

The latest release of Spark NLP 3.0 comes with over 1100+ pretrained models, pipelines, and Transformers in 190+ different languages. It also delivers massive speeds up on both CPU & GPU devices while extending support for the latest computing platforms such as new Databricks runtimes and EMR versions.

The talk will focus on how to scale Apache Spark / PySpark applications in YARN clusters, use GPU in Databricks new Apache Spark 3.x runtimes, and manage large-scale datasets in resource-demanding NLP applications efficiently. We will share benchmarks, tips & tricks, and lessons learned when scaling Spark NLP.

Register: https://events.johnsnowlabs.com/speed-optimization-benchmarks-in-spark-nlp-3-making-the-most-of-modern-hardware

title: Montreal R User Group: Crossing the AI Valley: Deploying and Monitoring Models in Production at Scale  [Virtual] , Canada, US/Canada
description:
Register: https://info.datascience.salon/crossing-the-ai-valley-of-death-deploying-monitoring-models-in-production

It‚Äôs happened again. You built another AI model that will never see the light of day because it won‚Äôt make it past the AI ‚Äúvalley of death‚Äù ‚Äì the crossover of model development to model deployment across your enterprise. The handoff between data science and engineering teams is fraught with friction, outstanding questions around governance and accountability, and who is responsible for different parts of the pipeline and process. Even worse? The patchwork approach when building an AI pipeline leaves many organizations open to risks because of a lack of a holistic approach to security and monitoring.

Join us to learn about approaches and solutions for configuring a ModelOps pipeline that‚Äôs right for your organization. You‚Äôll discover why it‚Äôs never too early to plan for operationalization of models, regardless of whether your organization has 1, 10, 100, or 1,000 models in production.

The discussion will also reveal the merits of an open container specification that allows you to easily package and deploy models in production from everywhere. Finally, new approaches for monitoring model drift and explainability will be revealed that will help manage expectations with business leaders all through a centralized AI software platform called Modzy¬Æ.

Register: https://info.datascience.salon/crossing-the-ai-valley-of-death-deploying-monitoring-models-in-production

title: Winnipeg R User Group: [Tunis R User Group] Introduction to Proteomics Using R  [Virtual] , Canada, US/Canada
description:
In support of the Global R User Group efforts to promote online events around the world featuring the R programming language, the Winnipeg R User Group is pleased to announce to our members this upcoming R user Group event put on by the Tunis R User Group.

Please RSVP and follow the attendance instructions at the original meet-up event page:

https://www.meetup.com/tunis-r-user-group/events/278773684/

______________________________________

We are happy to announce the start of our activities within Tunis R User Group (https://www.meetup.com/tunis-r-user-group/events/278773684/).

The first online workshop will serve as an introduction to proteomics using the programming language R. Join us to meet Dr. Laurent Gatto.

Dr. Laurent Gatto ( https://lgatto.github.io/about/) is an Associate Professor of Bioinformatics at the de Duve Institute, UCLouvain, in Belgium. His research group focuses on the development and application of statistical learning for the analysis and comprehension of large scale biological data. Since 2010, he has focused on the processing and analysis of mass spectrometry-based quantitative proteomics data in general, and spatial proteomics data in particular. The development and publication of scientific software is an integral part of his work, as reflected by his numerous contributions to the Bioconductor project. Laurent is an avid open research advocate, making his research outputs openly available. He is a Software Sustainability Institute fellow, a Data and Software Carpentry instructor and an ASAPbio ambassador.

Place: Zoom
Date/Time: Thursday, June 17, 2021 from 4PM to 7PM Tunisia time (GMT +1)

We recommend you to have a look at the convenient world clock website https://lnkd.in/gUAZxQM if you're struggling to find the right time according to your time zone.

Dr. Laurent will go through the first chapter of this material üëâ https://rformassspectrometry.github.io/docs/

In order to attend the meetup, please fill out this form üëâ https://tinyurl.com/taeuyum3

We will send you the Zoom link a few hours before the training session. Please check out your email later.

We look forward to welcoming you!

title: Cleveland R User Group: Jai Ranchod on pdftools and Bryan Lewis on DuckDB  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
This meetup we'll have two shorter talks by Jai Ranchod and Bryan Lewis. Details below.

Talk 1: Jai Ranchod - Extract tabular data from PDFs with pdftools

I'm going to be talking about how to pull tabular data out of a PDF based on partial string matching and some functions in the "PDF Tools" package. The need to do this presented itself when the president of the management company wanted a table of information for the 60+ properties in our portfolio and our software vendor said they could only give us PDFs of word docs.

Jai ("Jay") Ranchod is currently an Operations and Financial Analyst are Rose Community Management, a property management firm based in NYC with offices in Independence, OH. I started using R at my previous job at Epic Systems which is an electronic healthcare record company as part of the quality control process on their cognitive computing products. Since then I have taken several online classes in R, data science, and machine learning including a professional certificate program in data science taught using R. I have a bachelor's degree in physics from the College of Wooster and recently finished my MBA from John Carroll University.

Talk 2: Bryan Lewis - R and DuckDB

DuckDB (https://duckdb.org) is a new embedded SQL database library in the spirit of other embedded databases like SQLite. Unlike SQLite, DuckDB uses a column-oriented data layout (like R data frames) and has a particular focus on performance for interactive data analysis. DuckDB's integration with R is so complete that it can work directly on in-memory language objects without copying. This lets you use DuckDB directly on R data frames, including excellent support for dplyr.

I'll show some practical examples of R and DuckDB and share my thoughts how to best use these technologies together.

Bryan Lewis is a mathematician, author of the irlba and threejs R packages, and coauthor of the recent CRC textbook "A Computational Approach to Statistical Learning." He previously worked on Mike Stonebraker's open-source SciDB array database project.

Note: this talk will be recorded and posted on our YouTube channel.

title: Wiesbaden R User Group: R Coffee Break XL:  modeling linguistic variation in R  [Virtual] , Germany, Europe
description:
Hallo liebe R User,

Die R Coffee Break gibt einen kurzen Einblick in ein R- Thema. Als Plattform nutzen wir Zoom.
Und ganz wie die gepflegte Kaffeepause im B√ºro wird das Meetup am Nachmittag stattfinden. Achtung: Dieses Mal haben wir eine XL-Kaffeepause von 30 Minuten.

Wir freuen uns, dass Claus Weihs und Sarah Buschfeld von derTU Dortmund University √ºber ihre Arbeit im Bereich der Lingusistik vortragen. Hier ist ihre Vortragsank√ºndigung:

Combining Prediction and Interpretation in Decision Trees (PrInDT): modeling linguistic variation in R
In this presentation, we show that conditional inference trees and ensembles are suitable methods for modeling linguistic variation. As against earlier linguistic applications, however, we claim that their suitability is strongly increased if we combine prediction and interpretation. To that end, we have developed a statistical method in R, PrInDT (Prediction and Interpretation with Decision Trees), which we introduce and discuss in our presentation.

* Es handelt sich um einen englischsprachigen Vortrag.
* Es ist ein 30-min√ºtiger Vortrag

description:
Hello everyone! We would like to invite you to join a fellow R group event organised online. Please see event details below:
----------------------------------------------

At the next Brighton R meetup, we will be joined by two fantastic speakers, and we‚Äôre excited to reveal that our first speaker is Tobias Stalder

'ggameboy'. Or what else we can do with ggplot2

We are pleased to welcome Tobias Stalder, Project Associate R&D at Grolimund+Partner AG, to talk at the next Brighton R meetup.

Tobias will be sharing how he built a cool data visualisation package using ggplot2 that allows you to create custom coloured Gameboy pictures!

The gameboy_plot() function allows you to change the colours of every aspect of a Gameboy wireframe, including the ability to add custom screen text messages.

So, if you‚Äôre interested in learning about some fun data visualisation things you can get up to with your data in ggplot2, then this is a talk not to be missed!

Following the presentation, you will have an opportunity to ask questions about the project and chat with others from the local Brighton R community.

ggplot2 is part of the tidyverse ecosystem of R packages, which allows you to assign variables to your data and then map onto aesthetics. You can checkout Tobias‚Äôs Github here, which includes a repository about the ggameboy project.

More speakers to be announced soon!

title: Barcelona R User Group: Online event by R Lille: Reproducible Computation at Scale in R with {targets}  [Virtual] , Spain, Europe
description:
Hello everyone! We would like to invite you to join a fellow R group event organised online. Please see event details below:
----------------------------------------------

Original Meetup: https://www.meetup.com/R-Lille/events/277902715/

[Abstract]
The {targets} (https://docs.ropensci.org/targets/) R package enhances the reproducibility, scale, and maintainability of data science projects in computationally intense fields such as machine learning, Bayesian data analysis, and statistical genomics. {targets} resolves the dependency structure of the analysis pipeline, skips tasks that are already up to date, executes the rest with optional distributed computing, and manages data storage. {stantargets} (https://docs.ropensci.org/stantargets/) and similar packages extend {targets} to simplify pipeline construction for specialized use cases such as the validation of Bayesian models.

[Bio]
Will Landau (https://wlandau.github.io/) works at Eli Lilly and Company (https://www.lilly.com/) where he develops methods and tools for clinical statisticians, and he is the creator and maintainer of the targets and drake R packages. Will earned his PhD in Statistics at Iowa State University in 2016, where his dissertation research applied Bayesian methods, hierarchical models, and GPU computing to the analysis of RNA-seq data.

[About]
This event (in English) is organised by the R Lille user group (Lille, France).

Abstract:
Natural language processing (NLP) is a field within computational linguistics and artificial intelligence that enables computers to understand and interact with human language. During this workshop we will use {tidytext} to explore some of the common topics within NLP such as tokenization, how to remove common words known as stop words and carry out sentiment analysis.

title: New York Open Statistical Programming Meetup: Text Preprocessing in R  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
group: New York Open Statistical Programming Meetup
description:
Continuing virtually, this month we have a talk about text preprocessing.

Thank you to EcoHealth Alliance for providing the Zoom link.

Conversations during the meetup are encouraged in the monthly-meetup-chat channel in the nyhackr slack: https://nyhackr.org/slack.html

Outside the meetups we have two events planned:

The 2021 R Conference in NY, September 8-10 as both in-person and virtual: https://rstats.ai/nyr/
The Bayes and Stan workshop, July 14-16, fully virtual: https://www.tickettailor.com/events/landeranalytics/505284

About the Talk:
Text constitutes an ever-growing part of the data available to us today. However, it is a non-trivial task to transform text, represented as long strings of characters, into numbers that we can use in our statistical and machine learning models. This talk will focus on the {textrecipes} package and its recent advancements in the realm of text preprocessing.

About Emil:
Emil Hvitfeldt is a clinical data analyst working in healthcare, and an adjunct professor at American University teaching statistical machine learning with tidymodels. He is also an open-source R developer and author of the {textrecipes} package.

The talk will begin at 7 PM EDT and we will start admitting people to the event shortly before. Since this is completely remote there will be no pizza but everyone is encouraged to have pizza individually.

Prior knowledge of (non-spatial) graphic making and data handling with the {tidyverse} in R is recommended.

Speaker Bio:

Dorris Scott is the GIS Librarian and Social Science Data Curator at Washington University ‚Äì St. Louis, where she provides consultation on projects that use geospatial data along with providing training in various GIS software, programming applications of geospatial data, and data management. She also serves as a liaison between Washington University Libraries and social science departments assisting faculty with their data needs such as data management and data curation. Dorris received her PhD in Geography from the University of Georgia, with a specialization in GIS applications for public health.

title: R-Ladies Vancouver: Tidy Tuesday with RLadies Vancouver and RLadies Santa Barbara  [Virtual] , Canada, US/Canada
description:
We will be joining forces with R-Ladies Santa Barbara on June 22nd to work on some Tidy Tuesday plots together (https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday). Tidy Tuesday is an ongoing project by the R4DS Online Learning Community where a new dataset is posted each week aimed at helping learners practice their wrangling and visualization skills.

Don‚Äôt know where to start? During the start of the meeting, we will help you write some code together to get your plots started. We also included some resources below to help provide some inspiration!

Come out and meet some R-Ladies from Santa Barbara and try out some new data visualization skills with us!

Workshop details:
Date and time: June 22nd, 2021 at 6:00pm
Webinar link: RSVP to view link
Note: Meeting password is embedded in the link after the ?
If you have trouble getting into the meeting, please message Jasmine

See you there!

Yuka, Jasmine, Lisa, and Sayemin

**********************IMPORTANT************************

1. Have your computer and a steady internet connection ready

2. If this is your first R-Ladies event, please take a moment to review our R-Ladies Global code of conduct: https://github.com/rladies/.github/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

3. Who is allowed to attend the workshop?
Everyone is welcome to join us at our events and to be a part of our mission to empower gender minorities with the skills and knowledge to code in one of the top programming languages in data science, which is R.

To fulfill this mission we do ask participants to respect a focus on the encouragement and support for women and non-binary people during our events.

***
General workshop information:

-Please expect a hands-on session in a friendly and laid-back atmosphere where we are all encouraged to learn together.

- RStudio (Free at https://www.rstudio.com/products/rstudio/download/)

title: R-Ladies Boulder: RLadies Boulder Meetup #15: From csv to slippy map - intro to spatial data in R  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Hi Boulder UseRs! Join us for this month's virtual R Ladies Meetup! This month, Anna Spiers will be giving us an introduction to spatial data and map-making in R!

From Anna: Working with spatial data can feel as finicky as caring for your favorite houseplant - your attempts to help are rejected despite following instructions, and you look longingly at friends' and colleagues' masterpieces (i.e., maps/plants). This talk will introduce spatial data broadly, and cover some of the basic workflows and troubleshooting steps in R. Specifically, we will work with vector data, focus on the `sp` and `sf` libraries, and produce an interactive map in R. Example data and code will be provided.

We will be meeting over Zoom (Meeting link visible when you RSVP). Join us to connect with other R users in the Boulder area and learn some new techniques to apply in your work!

We hope you'll also join our local Slack workspace to keep the R help and conversation flowing! To get access to the Slack workspace, please fill out this short Google form: https://forms.gle/j36YGxuNwN6zZ8nW7.

title: R-Ladies Philly: R-Ladies Lightning Talks: How You Use R  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Join us in June for an evening of short and insightful talks related to using R. Topics will highlight the breadth of use cases our members solve using R and the packages they love. Stay tuned as we update the list of topics and speakers!

Agenda:
6:00 - 6:10 - Join online
6:10 - 6:20 - Welcome and announcement
6:20 - 7:20 - Talk part 1
7:20 - 7:25 - Short break
7:25 - 8:00 - Talk part 2

Speakers and talk titles:

* Shannon Pileggi - Leveraging the R community for the job interview

Shannon Pileggi (@PipingHotData) is an enthusiastic statistical collaborator and educator with experience partnering on data analysis in corporate, tech, and government settings. Shannon is currently a Senior Statistician at Adelphi Research in Doylestown, PA working in pharmaceutical market research. Shannon‚Äôs day-to-day in R include: fine-tuning ggplots to convey analysis results, contributing to an internal package to automate routine analyses/tasks, streamlining work-flows for repetitive analyses, and developing shiny aps.

* Alice Walsh - Data nightmares: True stories for scary data

Alice Walsh (@sciencealice), Ph.D. is a computational biologist who studies diseases at the molecular level. She is also an organizer of R-Ladies Philly and enjoys data cleaning, generating hypotheses from complex data, and mentoring others.

* Zhenya Cherkas - Rshiny : connecting the silos

Zhenya Cherkas is an Associate Director at Johnson & Johnson Global Medical Safety. Using R for over 15 years, she always worked on the better access and use of multiple disconnected data sources for better data science in less time. She holds PhD in Statistics, MS and BS in Mathematics and BS in Applied Mathematics and Computer Science.

* Jake Riley - Headliner: a new package for dynamic insights

Jake Riley is a data analyst at CHOP and the author of several R packages to improve the workflow of data analysis. His new R package, [headliner], allows users to generate dynamic, informative titles for charts and reports. Read more here https://rjake.github.io/headliner/"

* June Choe - Using icon fonts for data viz

June Choe (@yjunechoe) is a PhD student in Linguistics at the University of Pennsylvania, where he studies the mechanisms of human language acquisition and processing. He enjoys blogging about R and reading about data visualization in his free time.

* Madhavi Ratnagiri - Identification of pulmonary dysfunction using machine learning

Madhavi Ratnagiri is a research associate at the University of Delaware, with a PhD in Electrical Engineering and a Masters in Biomedical Engineering. Over the years she has worked with various types of data including speech, image and time sequence. She programs in C++, matlab, perl, R and most recently python.

title: R-Ladies Sydney: Building a Personal Website Using R   [Virtual] , Australia, Australia
description:
This workshop invites R users with basic/intermediate knowledge who are interested in learning how to build their personal website using the blogdown package (No prior knowledge with blogdown is required).

This workshop will be an interactive presentation, where we will build a website together (like Jenny's site here https://jennysloane.netlify.app/ from scratch. We will also provide further resources that will allow you to continue enhancing your website on your own.

To prepare for this workshop please make sure that you have R and RStudio installed on your computer. It would be great if you could create a Github account if you do not have one already.

Please bring your laptop with you!

NOTE: We are back to running workshops IN PERSON- YAY! Thank you to Nous for their generous support. The COVID-safe room limit is 20 attendees so please only RSVP if you are sure you can come.

BIOS

Tehilla is a Ph.D. student studying cognitive science at UNSW, Sydney. She received her Bachelor and Masters of Science degrees from the University of Basel, Switzerland. Her research focuses on the interaction between risky decision-making and information-seeking behaviour.

Jenny is also a PhD student studying cognitive psychology at UNSW. She received her BA in psychology from the University of Maryland and her Masters of Science in experimental psychology from Syracuse University. Jenny‚Äôs research interests include studying the effects of interruptions and time-pressure on decision-making.

title: R-Ladies Brisbane: Introduction to using Docker for reproducibility in R  [Virtual] , Australia, Australia
description:
*What are we going to learn:
Docker is a platform for creating ‚Äúcontainers‚Äù on your system. You can think of them like a mini system on your computer. They are completely self-contained, isolated environments on your system. These containers include their own operating system, application software, scripts, data, etc. Containers are useful for a lot of things, but here I‚Äôll focus on a quick introduction to using Docker for reproducibility in R. I will demonstrate on how to set-up Docker, run R on a Docker container and few other use cases.

*Who is going to present:
Malindrie is a PhD candidate at the Australian Institute for Bioengineering and Nanotechnology, The University of Queensland. She works on developing bioinformatics methods for the analysis of large-scale single-cell data using advanced statistical modelling and uses modern statistics tools to understand human disease. Malindrie completed her Bachelor of Science (Honours) degree in Statistics in 2016.

* When are we meeting?
The talk will start at 5:00 pm for approximately 45 mins and 15 min Q&A. After that we invite you to stay for in-person and/or virtual catch up.

************The presentation will start at 5:00 pm********************
* Where are we meeting?
We will meet at study room 01-W227, Law Library (Walter Harrison Library), UQ St. Lucia campus- this will be a hybrid event with a Zoom link available.

title: R-Ladies Freiburg: From messy data to beautiful plot: Guided TidyTuesday  [Virtual] , Germany, Europe
description:
Know the basics of data wrangling but want some hands-on practice? Want to learn ggplot tips and tricks to make your plots eye-catching? Seen cool visualizations on Twitter but find it hard to go from messy dataset to beautiful visualization?

In this monthly meetup, we‚Äôll go through a Tidy Tuesday dataset together step-by-step, walking you through the entire process from coming up with an interesting question to asnwer, getting the data in the right format and finally, creating a cool visualization!

You may have heard of Tidy Tuesday -- a weekly initiative by R for Data Science which provides a new dataset every week for the community to practice wrangling and visualizing. It has a huge Twitter community and is one of the best ways to practice and develop tidyverse skills, whether you‚Äôre still reviewing the basics or have quite the repertoire. This series has something for everyone and is especially designed to be beginner friendly!

It's important to us to ensure that Guided Tidy Tuesday is a safe space for gender minorities and especially those who are just starting out with R. Studies have shown that letting gender minorities speak first promotes a welcoming and supportive atmosphere for underrepresented groups. All are welcome at this meetup but we specifically ask cisgender men to take a passive role in this meetup and hold comments / questions until after others have had the chance to ask. Thank you for your support!

title: R-Ladies Freiburg: Tidy Text Analysis: Word frequencies & n-grams  [Virtual] , Germany, Europe
description:
Text is one of the most prominent and extensive data sources in the digital world. It can be an insight into consumer opinions, social media trends, and literary story arches. However, it can be difficult to analyze without specialized tools and commands. The tidytext package and framework makes it easy to go from full text files to clean data and ultimately, analysis!

The workshop will start with the building blocks of text analysis: separating a text into smaller chunks, removing punctuation, and identifying frequent words or phrases. If you‚Äôve joined our previous text analysis meetups before, this will be a great recap; if you haven‚Äôt, this will bring you right up to speed! We‚Äôll show you all you need to know so beginners to the topic are very much welcome.

The focus for the evening will be on going beyond individual words in isolation to n-grams: units of a set number of words (e.g. bigrams like ‚ÄúI think‚Äù, ‚Äúthink that‚Äù, ‚Äúthat tidytext‚Äù, ‚Äútidytext is‚Äù, ‚Äúis great‚Äù.). This will allow us to get a sense of context about words based on the company they keep and address typical text analysis problems (e.g. "happy" preceded by "not" being given a positive sentiment score).

We‚Äôll top it all off with some truly unique visualizations that show the relationship between words, like bigram network plots with ggraph. Materials will be based on the book Tidy Text Mining by Julia Silge and David Robinson (chapter 4).

title: AthensR: Reproducible Computation at Scale in R with {targets} [R Lille]  [Virtual] , Greece, Europe
description:
[Abstract]
The {targets} (https://docs.ropensci.org/targets/) R package enhances the reproducibility, scale, and maintainability of data science projects in computationally intense fields such as machine learning, Bayesian data analysis, and statistical genomics. {targets} resolves the dependency structure of the analysis pipeline, skips tasks that are already up to date, executes the rest with optional distributed computing, and manages data storage. {stantargets} (https://docs.ropensci.org/stantargets/) and similar packages extend {targets} to simplify pipeline construction for specialized use cases such as the validation of Bayesian models.

[Bio]
Will Landau (https://wlandau.github.io/) works at Eli Lilly and Company (https://www.lilly.com/) where he develops methods and tools for clinical statisticians, and he is the creator and maintainer of the targets and drake R packages. Will earned his PhD in Statistics at Iowa State University in 2016, where his dissertation research applied Bayesian methods, hierarchical models, and GPU computing to the analysis of RNA-seq data.

[About]
This event (in English) is organised by the R Lille user group (Lille, France).

title: AthensR: Introduction to NLP with R [Birmingham R User Group]  [Virtual] , Greece, Europe
description:
For the June meetup we will have one speaker: Nicolas Attalides. He will join us from London to talk about Natural Language Processing.

Abstract:
Natural language processing (NLP) is a field within computational linguistics and artificial intelligence that enables computers to understand and interact with human language. During this workshop we will use {tidytext} to explore some of the common topics within NLP such as tokenization, how to remove common words known as stop words and carry out sentiment analysis.

title: R-Ladies Madrid: Empezando con clusterizaci√≥n   [Virtual] , Spain, Europe
description:
En esta sesi√≥n comenzaremos a explorar c√≥mo de potentes son los m√©todos de clusterizaci√≥n para solucionar m√∫ltiples problemas y lo haremos a trav√©s de varios ejemplos.

Lo aprenderemos de la mano de Elena Rivas Ruzafa (https://www.linkedin.com/in/elena-rivas-ruzafa/) , Head of Engineering - Digital Products que durante la sesi√≥n nos guiar√° y aprenderemos mediante ejemplos.

Dentro del machine learning, la clusterizaci√≥n se enmarca dentro del aprendizaje no supervisado, es decir, esos algoritmos para los que solo disponemos de un conjunto de datos de entrada que no est√°n etiquetados y sobre los que obtendremos informaci√≥n sin conocer de antemano cu√°l ser√° la respuesta correcta. Esta situaci√≥n se da muy a menudo y provocar√° que la forma en la que hemos de testear los resultados sea muy particular. Tambi√©n veremos que la creaci√≥n de visualizaciones de datos y la generaci√≥n de gr√°ficos, se convertir√° en una parte esencial de la exploraci√≥n de dichos resultados.

Lo que obtendremos tras el proceso de clusterizaci√≥on ser√° una segmentaci√≥n de los datos en grupos similares que ser√°n lo que conocemos como ‚Äúcl√∫steres‚Äù. Aunque es un problema de clasificaci√≥n no debemos confundir clusterizaci√≥n con clasificaci√≥n. Ambos son m√©todos de identificaci√≥n de patrones, pero mientras el primero pertenece al aprendizaje no supervisado, el segundo, m√°s conocido, pertenece al aprendizaje supervisado. Tambi√©n trataremos de explicar estas diferencias.

Adem√°s de resolver algunos casos pr√°cticos durante la sesi√≥n, veremos c√≥mo estos m√©todos pueden solucionar diferentes problemas en m√∫ltiples √°mbitos (en medicina para el diagn√≥stico de enfermedades, en redes sociales para encontrar grupos de comportamiento similares, en finanzas para generar estrategias dirigidas a los diferentes grupos de clientes...)

Todo esto lo haremos en el entorno de programaci√≥n R en el que existen m√∫ltiples paquetes que implementan algoritmos de clustering y funciones para visualizar sus resultados. Durante la sesi√≥n trabajaremos con algunos de los m√°s interesantes.

Estas son las librer√≠as que usaremos, para que vay√°is instal√°ndolas. Las dos √∫ltimas son las espec√≠ficas de clustering:

library(tidyverse)
library(gridExtra)
library(dplyr)
library(reshape2)
library(ggmap)
library(factoextra) # clustering algorithms & visualization
library(cluster) # clustering algorithms

Aqu√≠ est√°n los materiales! https://github.com/rladies/meetup-presentations_madrid/blob/master/README.md#[masked]---taller-online

Nat√†lia Vilor Tejedor (@natvilortejedor): "Paseo aleatorio por la programaci√≥n (en femenino)" ~ 15 minutos

Biograf√≠a:
"
Natalia Vilor-Tejedor is a Postdoctoral Research Scientist at BarcelonaBeta Brain Research Center (BBRC), the Center for Genomic Regulation (CRG) and the Erasmus University Medical Center (EMC). Moreover, Natalia collaborates in teaching activities as an Assistant Professor in the Department of Mathematics at the Autonomous University of Barcelona (UAB), and in the Department of Systems Biology at the University of Vic (UVIC-UCC). N√∫ria Sal√°n (@nuriasalann): "El ingenio (in)visible" ~ 45 minutos

Inventoras que no salen en los libros de texto, nombres de mujeres que han hecho, consus inventos y descubrimientos, que nuestra vida sea m√°s f√°cil, m√°s c√≥moda, m√°s amable... pero siguen siendo desconocidas. En cambio, los nombres de los inventores salen en los libros y son visibles. Biograf√≠a:
"
Profesora de metalurgia en la ESEIAAT (UPC-Terrassa), y presidenta de la Societat Catalana de Tecnolog√≠a, he dedicado las dos √∫ltimas d√©cadas a rescatar nombres y viencias de mujeres de todas las √©pocas y lugares para hacerlas visibles y que puedan tener el reconocimiento que merecen. title: R-Ladies Amsterdam: [ONLINE]- R in Production  [Virtual] , Netherlands, Europe
description:
Hi, everybody!
We are super excited to have Veerle van Leemput with us, Managing Director and Head of Data Science from Analytic Health- sharing her knowledge with us on how to run R in production!

DESCRIPTION
-------------------
We often hear that R can‚Äôt be used for production, but is this true? Isn‚Äôt the statement that R is ‚Äòjust a research-only language mainly used by academia‚Äô outdated?

Spoiler alert: you definitely can use R in production. From ETL to (Shiny) web applications to machine learning models: some of the main business processes at Analytic Health are powered by R. During this talk, Veerle will dive into what ‚Äúproduction‚Äù means and how you can use R in a context outside of academia. By showing how R is being used at Analytic Health and how processes and applications are deployed and managed we hope to show you that R can do more than statistics only. This talk will inspire you to take R one step further, and by providing pointers to which tools you can use to build robust processes you‚Äôll leave this talk ready to use R in production yourself!

ABOUT VEERLE
---------------------

Veerle is an entrepreneur and Data Scientist who gets excited about data and programming. She is Managing Director and Head of Data Science at Analytic Health, a UK-based company that develops intelligent and accessible technology which gives organisations the tools they need to accelerate innovation in healthcare. She is a R developer with a Master‚Äôs Degree in Data Science and multiple years of experience in the pharmaceutical market. Besides programming in R (and Shiny) she also develops multiple web applications for healthcare organisations using Vue.js and Node.

Everyone is welcome to join us at our events and to be a part of our mission to empower gender minorities with the skills and knowledge to code in one of the top programming languages in data science, which is R.

title: K√∂ln R User Group: Virtual R Lightning Talks  [Virtual] , Germany, Europe
description:
PLEASE NOTE: One of our talks will be held in German!

Agenda:

## TALK 1

Rtangle - An R Wrapper to Scrape Facebook Page and Group Posts at Scale via the CrowdTangle API

About Marcel Schliebs:

Marcel Schliebs is a PhD student in social data science and researcher at the Programme on Democracy and Technology at the University of Oxford. He has previously developed statistical software both in academic and national security contexts.

## TALK 2

Deploy R to production with AWS Batch and Apache Airflow

About Markus Nutz:

Markus is currently working as a Data Scientist at OBI next, where he has spent the last two years building a customer data platform and putting analytical/data products into production. He is excited by all kind of data work. Markus holds a Bachelor in Political Science and a Master in Applied Data Science and Measurement.

## TALK 3

Intelligente Behandlung von Fehlwerten - gewusst wie!

Nahezu alle Rohdaten beinhalten Fehlwerte. Die Ursachen daf√ºr k√∂nnen vielf√§ltig sein, wie fehlerhafte Kodierung, Ziffernsturz, Probleme bei der Erfassung, nicht verf√ºgbar etc. Im Extremfall muss man das entsprechende Merkmal von der Analyse ausschlie√üen oder der Datensatz kann f√ºr die Analyse nicht genutzt werden ‚Äì beides ist jedoch unerw√ºnscht. Wie also damit umgehen? Gibt es bessere Techniken, um das Problem zu l√∂sen? Wie gro√ü ist der Aufwand, diese Techniken in der Praxis umzusetzen? Kann man den Vorgang automatisieren? Auf alle diese Fragen versucht der Vortrag eine Antwort zu geben.

√úber Helmut Grillenberger:

Helmut hat Statistik studiert und verf√ºgt √ºber eine langj√§hrige Erfahrung im analytischen Bereich. Dazu z√§hlt z. B. der Aufbau einer Analyseabteilung f√ºr Yves Rocher, die Umsetzung von DWH Konzepten und die Entwicklung von analytischen Anwendungen bei Peter Hahn, die Anonymisierung von Kundendaten f√ºr die M√ºnchener R√ºck mit R, die Entwicklung von R-Konzepten bei Siemens Financial Services, u.v.m.

Zu seinen Themen z√§hlen u. a. Statistik, maschinelles Lernen und neuronale Netze. Seine bevorzugte Programmiersprache ist R.

Er arbeitet als Analytiker und bietet f√ºr R einen Proof Of Concept an, indem ein R-Paket zu L√∂sung von Kundenproblemen erstellt wird. N√§here Informationen zur ‚ÄûR-Initiative‚Äú finden Sie hier: https://www.usedata.com/common/aufmacher/r-initiative.html

Er h√§lt au√üerdem Webinare zu den Themen ‚ÄûProfessionelle Erstellung wissenschaftlicher Arbeiten mithilfe von Bookdown‚Äú, ‚ÄûProfessionelle Erstellung von R-Paketen‚Äú, ‚ÄûWarum GIT?‚Äú, ‚ÄûPerfekt pr√§sentieren mit Powerpoint, Camtasia und Snagit‚Äú. Alle diese Webinare befinden sich auf Xing-Event. Kontaktanfragen auf Xing willkommen, Email gerne an [masked].

## Social Gathering

After the talks we want you to virtually meet, chat, network, and discuss interesting topics.

title: R-Ladies Tbilisi: First steps on Git using R-Studio and GitHub  [Virtual] , Georgia, Asia
description:
This R-Ladies Tbilisi meetup is happy to welcome Elisa Schneider (see bio below)! During this workshop we will introduce the concept of version control using Git, RStudio and GitHub. We will learn the basic Git commands and how to use them directly from R-Studio. Elisa Schneider will show how to link your R-Projects with GitHub to create online repositories to share your work and how it can be used for collaboration. At the end she will do a short demo on uploading a small WebPage to Github such as the one from R-Ladies Seattle https://github.com/rladies-seattle/rladies-seattle-organizing. If we have enough time she will introduce other possibilities such as GitHub Webpages like this one: https://kyla-mcconnell.github.io/website/index.html.

If you have some time to prepare before the Meetup, Elisa recommends to:
¬∑ create a GitHub account (if you do not have one yet) on https://github.com/
¬∑ download and install Git from https://git-scm.com/

For the last part of the meetup some very basic knowledge of markdown/Rmarkdown is recommended, but not mandatory, we will also go through it. If you want, you can have a look at the first 35 minutes of this video about RMarkdown: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=H91WSwALx1A

Bio
Elisa Schneider comes from Argentina. She studied Biology and also got a degree on Science Education. She specialized in Remote Sensing data analysis and Geographic Information Systems (GIS). She practiced as environmental assessment consultant and also taught cartography and GIS for park rangers. Thanks to a scholarship from the German Academic Exchange Service she was able to complete a master on Environmental Modeling in 2019, at the University of Freiburg. Since then she has been working on the Forest Reaserch Institute of Baden-W√ºrttemberg, Germany evaluating forest health from remote sensing data, modeling species distribution and outbreaks of pest insects under climate change. In 2019 she joined R-Ladies Freiburg as a Co-Organizer.

title: R-Ladies Milan: Modelli predittivi per la crescita profittevole: il caso Bene Assicurazioni  [Virtual] , Italy, Europe
description:
In questo evento siamo lieti di ospitare un workshop pratico di Bene Assicurazioni, che condivider√† con noi come stanno risolvendo le loro sfide quotidiane utilizzando R & big data.

Bene Assicurazioni √® una realt√† in crescita dalla struttura agile, con molteplici partnership e un modello di business in omni-canalit√†. La Compagnia ha completato la digitalizzazione dei processi e crede nel continuo aggiornamento delle tecnologie adottate.

Il team BI&A √® un gruppo in crescita e con una posizione centrale nella compagnia; √® un gruppo giovane, dinamico che si occupa:

Della diffusione della ‚Äúcultura dei numeri‚Äù all‚Äôinterno della Compagnia
Del governo integrato della reportistica, degli indicatori di performance e di marginalit√† tecnica
Delle analisi predittive, tecniche e attuariali per ottimizzare il pricing competitivo, la retention e lo sviluppo di nuovi prodotti
Dato il piano di crescita della compagnia, molto ambizioso nel breve-medio termine e da effettuarsi senza intaccare la marginalit√†, abbiamo studiato con diversi modelli predittivi come modificare il prodotto e il pricing per ottimizzare le nostra crescita, ottenendo infine risultati in linea con le aspettative (Machine Learning works!).

In questo workshop presentiamo il problema ed entriamo nei dettagli di alcuni dei modelli, dei test effettuati e del codice utilizzato per raggiungere il nostro obiettivo.

L'evento sar√† in Italiano e sar√† trasmesso in streaming tramite Zoom (Non √® necessario installare zoom).
Il materiale per il workshop sar√† condiviso prima dell'evento.

AGENDA
- Chi siamo ‚Äì Bene Assicurazioni e il Team BI&A
- Perch√© abbiamo utilizzato modelli predittivi per stimare la conversion e che risultati abbiamo ottenuto
- Descrizione dei principali algoritmi utilizzati per il modello di conversion e che criteri abbiamo utilizzato per la selezione
- Walk-through di un codice di esempio

Speakers:
+Alessandra Guazzi: Responsabile BI&A e Direct Product Manager;Laureata in Matematica, con un'esperienza di dottorato di ricerca, lavora in Allianz SE come Data Analyst e partecipa all'avvio di un team dedicato all'ottimizzazione dei prezzi per Allianz Australia (Direct). Dopo un'incursione in campo biomedico, lavora come manager in pricing & analytics presso Willis Towers Watson e nel gruppo Cerved.
+Alessandra Villa: Senior Pricing Expert; Laureata in Scienze Statistiche ed Economiche, lavora come attuario presso Zurich Connect per 4 anni, per poi passare a un'esperienza come Pricing Developer in AM Trust. √à in Bene Assicurazioni da 2 anni, coordinando le attivit√† di Pricing e Reportistica degli andamenti tecnici.
+Giulia Del Monaco: Data Analyst: Laureata in Biostatistica, inizia a lavorare in Bene nel 2020, dopo 2 esperienze in consulenza (Telematics e Pharma) come data analyst. Ha ottenuto il master in Big Data & Business Analytics del Sole 240re, dove ha supportato il docente con attivit√† di tutoring. Si occupa principalmente di automazione e modelli predittivi in R.
+Simone Cavenago: BI Analyst; Laureato in Scienze Statistiche ed Economiche, inizia a lavorare per Bene Assicurazioni nel 2018. Come principale responsabilit√†, segue la preparazione ed analisi dei dati e mantiene e sviluppa sulla piattaforma di Business Intelligence (bReport), tutta la reportistica direzionale e dedicata alle agenzie.

Non vedo l'ora di incontrarvi!

title: R-Ladies New York: Data Visualization: Color Palettes, Themes, and Schemes  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
For our June event, R-Ladies Anna Sofia Kircher and Joyce Robbins will share short talks about using color palettes, themes, and schemes to improve data visualization in R.

This event will be hosted over Zoom, and the link will be available on this Meetup page at noon on the day of the event.

Agenda (times approximate):
7-7:05 pm: R-Ladies NYC Announcements
7:05-7:30: ‚Äúggplot and I‚Äù by Anna Sofia Kircher
7:30-7:55: ‚ÄúDoes your color palette match your data?‚Äù by Joyce Robbins
7:55-8:15: Questions and wrap-up

--- Talk Abstract ---

‚Äúggplot and I‚Äù
Speaker: Anna Sofia Kircher

Abstract: This talk will be about how to use ggplot themes and how to personalize them for your purposes. This is motivated by my own obsession with colors and my own experience that different plots with different audiences respond differently to different themes.

Bio: Anna Sofia Kircher is the data scientist at Lendable and works with data of various fintechs in emerging and frontier markets.

‚ÄúDoes your color palette match your data?‚Äù
Speaker: Joyce Robbins

Abstract: One of the most common graphical mistakes is choosing an inappropriate color scheme for your data. In this talk, I‚Äôll explain how sequential, diverging and qualitative color schemes are each suited to a different type of data. We‚Äôll then look at a variety of plots that could be improved with alternative color choices. My hope is that these examples will serve as conversation starters for a lively discussion on matching color to data.

Bio: Joyce Robbins (@jtrnyc) is a Lecturer in the Department of Statistics at Columbia University. She specializes in data visualization and statistical literacy.

---

R-Ladies is dedicated to providing a harassment-free experience for everyone. We do not tolerate harassment of participants in any form. Please take a moment to review the R-Ladies Global code of conduct (particularly if this is your first time attending!): https://rladies.org/code-of-conduct

title: Orange County R Users Group (OCRUG): Interview Take-home Challenges  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Are you looking to land a data science job and want to practice take-home challenges? Did you spend hours and hours on take-home challenges which supposed to be finished in under 3 hours but have no feedback? Come join us for a coding camp. It will be headed up by Xi Chen. The idea is to motivate us to code and sharpen our skills. This will help all of us so you never have to worry about the technical interview again.

The format will be that the organizer will hand out two take-home challenges one week in advance. You can choose either one or both to complete by yourself. Feel free to use Python or R. We will then discuss them together during the session.

The expectations are that you will actually make effort to do the take-home problems each week. If you cannot make a commitment, please wait until the next club starts. It is expected that participants will complete the challenges or do the best they can within 3 hours. Experience suggests that this is a lower limit and it can be much more time.

We will meet each week, Wednesday between 6:30 and 8:00 PM PST for six weeks. The first dataset will go out on July 7th.

Signing up: When you sign-up you will be placed on the waiting list. We always have a lot of interest but the club is a significant commitment. The coordinator will confirm your commitment. Please make sure that you get meet-up emails.

If you aren't vaccinated, you still have time as doses are becoming widely available! Please visit the Illinois Department of Health COVID-19 Vaccine FAQ page for more details. (https://www.dph.illinois.gov/covid19/vaccine-faq)

As always, please reach out to us with any questions or concerns. We look forward to seeing you live and in person at the Haymarket Pub & Brewery soon!

title: CaRdiff - the Cardiff R User Group: Tidy Thursday: Summer 2021 Remote Workshop  [Virtual] , United Kingdom, Europe
group: CaRdiff - the Cardiff R User Group
description:
Come join us for this next Tidy Thursday session.

Tidy Tuesdays are weekly R projects on 'tidying' data, associated (but not exclusive!) to the 'tidyverse': ggplot2, dplyr, tidyr and friends.

You can find out more about Tidy Tuesdays here: https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday

We will meet (on Thursday!), find the most recent data set and 'tidy' it up together.

++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
Dataset TBC on Monday
++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

This session will be beginner-friendly, hands-on, and potentially pair programming driven.

Learning outcomes: Data Preparation, Data Munging, Tidy Data, Tidyverse

It would be helpful for attendees to have the following already installed, but if you run into trouble we can help on the day.

* R: https://www.r-project.org/
* R Studio desktop: https://rstudio.com/products/rstudio/
* Tidyverse: https://www.tidyverse.org/

These are all free tools, and install will take roughly 20-40 min depending on hardware and internet speeds.

Our previous work is available here:
https://github.com/CaRdiffR/tidy_thursdays

title: Berlin R Users Group: #45 A long-short Bayesian State-Space model with R and RStan  [Virtual] , Germany, Europe
description:
Welcome to our 2nd own Berlin RUG online meetup! We'll learn about bayesian modeling for a forecast on our upcoming election. And we will get to see each other again, so we're hoping many will sign up :)

A long-short Bayesian State-Space model for the German Federal Election 2021 with R and RStan

# Description
Marcus Gro√ü and Michelle Golchert will present a Bayesian model for forecasting the German federal election 2021 with R and RStan that gives more insights and more accurate predictions compared to simple poll-averaging methods. The model consists of two parts:
A model for the election outcome (i.e. the vote share for each party based on poll data) and a model to assign a probability to the coalition of the actual government using expert survey data. An in-depth description and motivation is discussed in this talk. The model is fitted with (R)Stan, a Bayesian modeling framework, that can seamlessly be integrated into R.

# Agenda
18:30 Intro
18:35 Talk
19:05 Q&A
19:30 Closing remarks (we can extend it if needed)

# Bios
Marcus Gro√ü and Michelle Golchert are Data Scientists at INWT Statistics.
Marcus holds a Ph.D. in Statistics and has several years experience consulting on and managing projects in the data science field. He is an expert in predictive analytics and Bayesian statistics.
Michelle has a master's degree in psychology and specializes in supporting Data Science projects in the areas of software development, DevOps and CI.

title: Greater Boston useR Group (R Programming Language): Virtual Boston useR July Meetup!  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
group: Greater Boston useR Group (R Programming Language)
description:
*please note the date change to 7/26 so that we do not overlap with useR! conference

Boston useR July Meetup!
Presentations by Kaija Gahm & Ralph Asher

Agenda:
12-12:05 - welcome & introductions
12:05 - 12:20 - Kaija Gahm: greenT Shiny app
12:20 - 12:40 - Ralph Asher: Introduction to Monte Carlo simulation, using Shiny
12:40 - 1:00 - Q&A

*greenT Shiny app:
greenT is a Shiny app I built to explore grapheme-color synesthesia, a neurological phenomenon where letters/numbers (graphemes) are associated with colors in my mind. Whenever friends found out about my synesthesia, they would want to know what color their names were in my head, and it got to be challenging to explain. When I found myself manually coloring squares in a spreadsheet to demonstrate what I saw in my mind's eye, I decided to build an app instead. The app lets you either set your own colors or see what mine look like. Then you can enter text, and it will display as a series of rectangles according to the colors you've selected. I also added a feature that mimics a Google form to collect survey responses from other people with synesthesia, so they can submit their color data if they want to.

Bio:
My name is Kaija (rhymes with Maya), and I'm an incoming PhD student in the ecology/evolutionary biology department at UCLA, where I'll be studying movement ecology and behavior of vultures using social network analysis. I've been using R for about six years, and for the past year I've been working as a data manager for an ecosystem science nonprofit. I'm on the board of SORTEE, an organization focused on openness and reproducibility in ecology and evolutionary biology. I didn't come from a computer science background, so I'm passionate about talking to people about incorporating R into their work in accessible and friendly ways.

When I'm not at my computer, you can usually find me outdoors (hiking or birdwatching) or spending entire days in the kitchen making up recipes. I tweet and blog, mostly about R.

*Introduction to Monte Carlo simulation, using Shiny
Monte Carlo Simulation is a powerful methodology to model and understand the impact of uncertainty upon real life. In this talk, I will introduce Monte Carlo simulation through a simple example: I'm meeting my neighbor after work for dinner in our neighborhood. Given the uncertain length of our commutes, will we make it in time for our reservation? I'll talk through the scenario, then walk through a simple Shiny app that explores the power of Monte Carlo Simulation to recommend decisions under uncertainty.

Bio:
I am Ralph Asher, and I am the founder of Data Driven Supply Chain LLC, a Minnesota-based consultancy that helps organizations apply data science and AI methods, including simulation, to design and improve their supply chain. Prior to founding Data Driven Supply Chain, I worked as an Operations Research Scientist at Target, designing e-commerce supply chain networks, and at General Mills, designing warehousing networks. I have used R for supply chain analytics for over eight years at these companies. I live in the Minneapolis, MN area and love running in the (usually cool) Minnesota air. I can be reached at [masked]

title: Montreal R User Group: DSSVirtual | Retail & Ecommerce  [Virtual] , Canada, US/Canada
description:
Register: https://info.datascience.salon/crossing-the-ai-valley-of-death-deploying-monitoring-models-in-production

It‚Äôs happened again. You built another AI model that will never see the light of day because it won‚Äôt make it past the AI ‚Äúvalley of death‚Äù ‚Äì the crossover of model development to model deployment across your enterprise. The handoff between data science and engineering teams is fraught with friction, outstanding questions around governance and accountability, and who is responsible for different parts of the pipeline and process. Even worse? The patchwork approach when building an AI pipeline leaves many organizations open to risks because of a lack of a holistic approach to security and monitoring.

Join us to learn about approaches and solutions for configuring a ModelOps pipeline that‚Äôs right for your organization. You‚Äôll discover why it‚Äôs never too early to plan for operationalization of models, regardless of whether your organization has 1, 10, 100, or 1,000 models in production.

The discussion will also reveal the merits of an open container specification that allows you to easily package and deploy models in production from everywhere. Finally, new approaches for monitoring model drift and explainability will be revealed that will help manage expectations with business leaders all through a centralized AI software platform called Modzy¬Æ.

Register: https://info.datascience.salon/crossing-the-ai-valley-of-death-deploying-monitoring-models-in-production

title: Montreal R User Group: DSSelevate | Elevating Women in Data  [Virtual] , Canada, US/Canada
description:
For Full Details and To Save Your Spot, Visit Here:
https://www.datascience.salon/dsse-virtual-2021/

Data Science Salon Elevate is a unique women focused virtual conference that includes BIPOC, members of the LGBTQIA+, and other underrepresented groups. This event series brings together specialists to educate each other, illuminate best practices and innovate new solutions. Learn as these thought leaders share their wisdom and experience in their chosen field.

About:
DSSe is an initiative to elevate and connect the voices of women in data science and encourage companies to set better standards in hiring women for data-intense roles. To expand our mission, we are committed to creating the most inclusive and diverse community for women including BIPOC, members of the LGBTQIA+, and other underrepresented groups. By elevating our community, we have the opportunity to build a truly incredible and thriving field that influences decision-making at every level in a meaningful way.
DSSe is important because the field of Data Science is still young ‚Äî for it to fulfill its true potential, we need voices that reflect the full experience of the world we live in to contextualize our data-derived insights.

For Full Details and To Save Your Spot, Visit Here:
https://www.datascience.salon/dsse-virtual-2021/

title: Cleveland R User Group: Trang Le: Take a sad chart and make it better  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Every good chart started out as a bad one. In this talk, we will discuss a few basic visualization principles and some ggplot tips and tricks that help improve our charts and refine our data stories. Some familiarity with R and ggplot will be useful but not required - novice R users are encouraged to attend.

Trang Le is a postdoctoral fellow with Jason Moore at the Computational Genetics Lab, University of Pennsylvania. She enjoys developing machine learning methods for rigorous analyses of a wide array of biomedical data. Most recently, her work focuses on investigating the long-term effect of neurological conditions in COVID-19 patients. She‚Äôs the author and maintainer of multiple R packages.

Note: this talk will be recorded and posted on our YouTube channel.

title: Salt Lake City R Users Group: Create infographics with R  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
group: Salt Lake City R Users Group
description:
Our August Meetup will be a remote gathering; the Zoom link will be posted the week of the event.

Infographics are everywhere, and when well-designed can be a fantastic way of sharing data highlights in an engaging and visually appealing way to non-technical audiences. Typically infographics are custom made by a graphic designer who has been provided the numbers that will be represented in the graphic, and therefore can be time-intensive to produce. Producing more than one infographic of the same design to display different values (for instance, for different geographical areas) has a linear increase in production time for each n+1 graphic once the basic design time has been accounted for. This talk will describe a novel method for producing infographics using R that allows for dynamically adjusting the graphical elements based on any number of data values and rapidly producing bespoke versions. A walkthrough of the process used to create 3,142 custom infographics (one for each county in the US) will be presented to illustrate the process.

Jonathan Zadra, PhD is a Director of Data Science at the non-profit Sorenson Impact Center in Salt Lake City, Utah. He combines his skills in statistics, programming, and data visualization with expertise in data privacy and policy to empower governments, nonprofits, and philanthropists working in a wide array of issue areas. His areas of focus include criminal justice data (including work with the PEW Charitable Trusts, Utah Department of Corrections, Utah Indigent Defense Commission, and Utah Commission on Criminal and Juvenile Justice), early- and higher-education data including a multi-year project supported by the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, as well as other issue areas like homelessness or poverty, and has worked on many smaller projects building evaluations and impact measurements for a variety of social-good non-profits around the country. He received his doctorate from the University of Virginia, where he studied cognitive science and neuroscience and designed and conducted rigorous RCTs - and also fell in love with R way back in 2006!

title: Portland R User Group: aggregate: meet, greet, learn, collaborate  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Hey folks, we were off last month but aggregate is back for July. This meetup will be online but we are discussing the potential return to in-person meetups so be on the lookup for those at a future date.

Please join us for the 42nd R aggRegate meetup on Zoom! We welcome current or aspiring R users who have any level of experience with the R programming language.

Our goal is to exchange knowledge, learn new skills, help each other troubleshoot coding problems, and meet new fellow R users.

No topic is off limits, and you may attend even if you don‚Äôt feel that you have anything to share. Come learn with us!

When: Wednesday, July 21st, 2021 @ 6:30-8 PM

Where: Online: zoom info provided soon (provided after you join).

Details: Marley Buchman will lead a discussion and present a demo of a Shiny app with persistent data. Typically Shiny apps are developed in a way in which the state of the app resets every time the app is accessed. Some applications would benefit from being able to save the state of the app upon exiting, and we will walk through one approach in doing that.

Agenda:

‚Ä¢ Marley's short demonstration of persistent data storage in Shiny

‚Ä¢ Brief intro/R project or problem: We'll take turns talking about an R project we're working on, a data/data-science problem, or something we want to learn, etc.

‚Ä¢ Next, anyone can share some code they've been working on and want help with / want feedback on. Make sure to have this ready before the meeting.

‚Ä¢ Before arriving, use the pdxrlang/aggregate GitHub repository to discuss ideas for things to work on at aggregate - https://github.com/pdxrlang/aggregate/issues

Please note that this event, like all PDX R events, adheres to the PDX R Code of Conduct: https://pdxrlang.com/code-of-conduct.html We are dedicated to a safe learning environment to all.

If you have any trouble message Marley Buchman in in the Meetup app, or on Twitter at @pdxrlang
